results are in! An overworked N-L tabulations staff
worked long into last night, furiously collating the data
from the "Who is your worst professor?" poll. The poll,
issued two weeks ago, received an overwhelming response
- the heavier mail days required three of the burlier
members of the delivery crew to tote the stacks of
responses back to the Gatehouse. Once all the entries
were in, the N-L consulted famous social scientist and
amateur pollster M.R. Bongue to select a scientifically
accurate sampling of the responses. After extensive
cooperative research with Dr. Bongue, the staff came up
with the 33 random entries that most exactly represent
the collective Hopkins undergraduate.
The entries, on the whole, indicated a creative impulse
hidden within the deepest pre-med recesses of the average
Hopkins student. Most replies took the liberty of
providing answers outside the strict yes/no requests, of
writing extensive comments where one word would have
sufficed, of posing questions in response to questions; in
short, it seems a lot of talent on campus has been
smothered under multiple-choice exams and
problem-gutted homework.
To start, the "Faculty" section evoked the widest range
of responses. No less than 29 personages were bestowed
the title of "Favorite Professor," coming from all
departments. Multiple nods went to Drs. Gryder, Crenson,
Cone, Pfeffer, Posner, and Russel-Wood. Honorable
mentions would take too much space to list -- you know
Who you are, so keep up the good work.
The Henny Youngman Award for best jokes went to
Michael Hooker (Philosophy), in a tight contest with
those who found no professor capable of delivering a
one-liner at the appropriate moment. One reply gave a
backhanded compliment to Robert Green, "for stealing
the best jokes from Dr. Pond."
Dr. Richard Macksey of the Humanities Center took
honors'in the art of obsfucation, although a number of
voters picked Drs. Ranum and Kenner as masters of the
verbal footnote. 8s for the worst advisor; well, a plurality
recommended staying away from Gilman 155 for course
counseling. At the same time, a sizeable vote came in for
Dr. Dierman, even though it wasn't technically his
category (see below).

shocks we might rather deny. .That, however, is

captive audience.

In Lance's dramatic monologue, Percy has
abandoned his characteristically smooth style.
Now, the words both repel and hold us. The
dignified desperation of the other novels has
become savage outrage. The subtle paring-knife
humor has become a guillotine. And we are the
potential victims.
A fallen Southern gentleman and souring liberal
lawyer, Lance is stagnating in a modern age which
affords him neither direction nor identity. He is
the "Knight of the Unholy Grail," fading into
non-existence, when suddenly the discovery of his
wife's infidelity leads him to a critical revelation :
that there is a here and now, that it is intolerable,
and that he can do something about it. The actions
Lance undertakes, and the plans he evolves for a
New World, are based upon the "Great Secret of
Life 'as he discerns it: 'God's secret design for
man is that man's happiness lies for men in men
practicing violence upon women and that women's
happiness lies in submitting to it. The secret of life
is violence and rape."
You may disagree with Ithat, perhaps violently.
It is difficult, in any case, not to concur with
Lance's (Percy's?) grim diagnosis of modern
American life, especially his bleakly accurate
depiction 'of our sexual maladies. The picture is
shocking, sobering—1 intolerable, Lance would say.
If the present is intolerable, the past is even
more so. Like many of us, Lance turns to the past
seeking a reaffirmation of the validity and
inevitability of his present condition: things just
have to be this way. But the past only reveals
roads not taken, false triumphs, fragments shored
against his ruins. The present receives neither

justification nor clarification from the past. For
Lance, "the mystery lies in the here and now,"
and it grows ever more mysterious as one comes to
recognize the overwhelming magnitude of that
central question : "What is one to do with
oneself?" \It may be the case that what Lance
does is in fact his undoing.
Lance's story oscillates between a dark perverse
despair and a strange frenzied hope. Reading it is
like taking a wild roller coaster ride. As much as
you might want to, you can't get off. And in the
end, you're left both exhausted and exhilarated,
•and perhaps a bit weak in the knees. That is
understandable. For, if nothing else, the visions of
Lancelot will shake you. Maybe even scare the hell
out of you.

Press. $3.95 in quality paperback format, $8.95 ill
hardcover.)
By GARY SMITH
"There were no more heroes."
So opens "Superfolks," Robert Mayer's comic
book in novel form. His first published novel, it is
a funny and often irreverent fiction, written for
adults who grew up hiding Dell comics in their
geography text books, about the one superhero
left, the greatest superhero of them all.
Who might this paragon of power be? Not
Batman and/or Robin. They were killed in a
traffic smash-up. Superman? He's missing,
presumed dead, after a K ryptonite meteor
slammed into Metropolis. Wonder Woman? She's
,voluntarily given up her powers and become a
spokesperson for Women's Lib. The Lone Ranger
caught an arrow in the back, and Tonto ran off to
Wounded iKnee. Which leaves...
...A creation of Mayer's fertile imagination, one
very close to Superman and going by the name of
David Brinkley. In any case, that's his civilian
name. He was sent to Earth as an infant from the
planet Cronk, left a flourishing career as an ace
young reporter at a great metropolitan newspaper
for broadcasting, but missed the smell of printer's
ink. Now he's Oven up the airwaves, in both
senses, and has his feet tied securely to the copy
desk of his old newspaper. He's 42, married, the
father of two children, has a nice wife and blue
hair. He's vulnerable to only one substance:
Cronkite —and perhaps the ravages of time,
because, after eight years of retirement, his
super-powers are definitely on the wane.
He has had attacks of weakness and has lost
confidence in himself—as well as in the general
order. What could any superhero do faced with
political assassinations, racial disturbances,
Vietnam and rampant street crime? The world has
come of age and the problems seem
insurmountable.
That is how Brinkley feels until a fateful news
flash draws him unexpectedly out of his suburban
shell and back into the real world of crime and
violence. But he has been devitalized so much that
he crashes into atree in hisfirst attempt to leap tall
buildings. Is there a criminal mastermind, and a
foul plot to dispose of the last of the superheroes?
The plot thickens...
"Superfolks" is a good, old-fashioned
mis-adventure story made contemporary by liberal
doses of political intrigue, sex and some hilarious
examples of celebrity malapropisms. Mayer
handles it all with grace and ease.
And well he might. First novel or not, his name
ought to have a familiar ring to it. For 10 years he
was reporter and later a columnist for Newsday, a
great metropolitan newspaper. While he was there
he won numerous awards for writing excellence,
including a National Headliners' Club award.
Mayer seems to have kept his foot on the
accelerator the whole time in the story. It has a
sparkling beginning, just the slightest trace of
middle-pages spread and a clever end. The work is
a whole, and a whole lot of fun, due to the
author's skill and imagination. I His gibes at the
news industry and other writers have punch and
style, especially the parody on Norman Mailer's highly personal and often excessive style of
reportage.
"Superfolks" is the kind of book that could give
lightweight fiction a good name. It is some of the
best of recent efforts at the genre, written to
entertain. Give it a read. It's far better than any
night of the week on TV.

By ERIC GARLAND
This year's Spring Fair didn't seem to bring as many
people to Hopkins as in the past; it also escaped a rainy
washout for three straight days. What the Mardi Gras did
get, however, was a mixture of violence and police
activity that, in retrospect, has been unusually absent
from past fairs.
NMth anywhere from ten to forty thousand people on
campus for a day, drinking beer and smoking dope, taking
ninety-degree heat and waiting in long lines, it should be
expected that a few among the crowd will get punchy-by
late afternoon. Especially those few that happen to be
ragged local punks or overeager lacrosse players—it
doesn't take too many Schlitz lights or poorly-chosen
words to bring out the worst in people.
The knifing incidents in the freshman quad are general
knowledge: one Hopkins student slashed and a teenager
cut in a back-and-forth brawl around the ride area. Along
with this well-known melee, there were a number of
minor scuffles. One in particular took place about a
half-hour before the stabbings, precipitated by the same
group responsible for the later scuffles.
Characterizing the Friday night fight was a uniform
lack of sensible action by the campus police. Those
on-hand for the entire affair, and others involved in
isolated fistfights, had common complaints about the
fumblings of the blue-uniformed security force. After the
initial outburst in the freshman quad—rather serious with
one man ganged up on by local youths—the campus cops
failed to respond to repeated warnings and identifications
of the troublemakers. Instead, they waited for the arrival
of city police, making no attempts at crowd control and
staying clear of those pointed out as brawlers, the ones
who would later start the knife fights. "The cops were
Intimidated more. than anything, just scared," said one
obFrvor.

or-

%en the city police got to the freshmen quad they
received little help from campus security in the way of
rounding up the instigators. Outside of the people stabbed
or those who actually fought with the city police, the
original gang that had been repeatedly identified to the
campus police was relatively ignored (in fact, they
reappeared Sunday at the Fair, ready for more
encounters.)
Once the city police cleared the amusement area in the
freshman quad, they toliped.off a confused evening by
proceeding to the Gilman Quad, where a jazz band had
been scheduled for a 9:30 show. The band had moved
indoors to the Glass Pavilion, apparently for fear of rain. •
Unfortunately, there was little notice given to those

milling about the Quad, wondering what had become of
the performance. The police then came into the Quad,
saw the crowd of people that seemed to be loitering for
no reason, and with the ride-area hubbub fresh in their
minds, went about kicking everyone out of the area.
Numerous complaints were voiced about the over-reaction
of the police, of excessive hassling of those that happened
to have a plastic beer cup in hand.
Thus the Mardi Gras, with its theme of insanity amid
revelry, had an offshoot of violence that was grossly
mishandled at the start, and then typically over-reacted to
at the end. Next year's Fair will have that to go on.

been passed in many countries forbidding such
situations, but bribery and the big stakes involved
prevent their enforcement. The Young
Republicans speak of freedom, of the choice
American workers have to join a union, but the
only way American business can compete with
such competition is to maintain the same
conditions in order to keep overhead low. I do not
concur with the Young Democrats' whplehearted
support of unionization, but it is obvious here that
there is something involved beyond the interests of
the people. They are just the pawns caught
between the struggles of two power and
money-hungry concerns. To support either the
unions or the Stevens Company would be to
neglect those with whom the issue is truly
concerned—the workers.

'Working conditions are poor,
wages are low,

In Lance's dramatic monologue, Percy has
abandoned his characteristically smooth style.
Now, the words both repel and hold us. The
dignified desperation of the other novels has
become savage outrage. The subtle paring-knife
humor has become a guillotine. And we are the
potential victims.
A fallen Southern gentleman and souring liberal
lawyer, Lance is stagnating in a modern age which
affords him neither direction nor identity. He is
the "Knight of the Unholy Grail," fading into
non-existence, when suddenly the discovery of his
wife's infidelity leads him to a critical revelation :
that there is a here and now, that it is intolerable,
and that he can do something about it. The actions
Lance undertakes, and the plans he evolves for a
New World, are based upon the "Great Secret of
Life 'as he discerns it: 'God's secret design for
man is that man's happiness lies for men in men
practicing violence upon women and that women's
happiness lies in submitting to it. The secret of life
is violence and rape."
You may disagree with Ithat, perhaps violently.
It is difficult, in any case, not to concur with
Lance's (Percy's?) grim diagnosis of modern
American life, especially his bleakly accurate
depiction 'of our sexual maladies. The picture is
shocking, sobering—1 intolerable, Lance would say.
If the present is intolerable, the past is even
more so. Like many of us, Lance turns to the past
seeking a reaffirmation of the validity and
inevitability of his present condition: things just
have to be this way. But the past only reveals
roads not taken, false triumphs, fragments shored
against his ruins. The present receives neither

justification nor clarification from the past. For
Lance, "the mystery lies in the here and now,"
and it grows ever more mysterious as one comes to
recognize the overwhelming magnitude of that
central question : "What is one to do with
oneself?" \It may be the case that what Lance
does is in fact his undoing.
Lance's story oscillates between a dark perverse
despair and a strange frenzied hope. Reading it is
like taking a wild roller coaster ride. As much as
you might want to, you can't get off. And in the
end, you're left both exhausted and exhilarated,
•and perhaps a bit weak in the knees. That is
understandable. For, if nothing else, the visions of
Lancelot will shake you. Maybe even scare the hell
out of you.

Press. $3.95 in quality paperback format, $8.95 ill
hardcover.)
By GARY SMITH
"There were no more heroes."
So opens "Superfolks," Robert Mayer's comic
book in novel form. His first published novel, it is
a funny and often irreverent fiction, written for
adults who grew up hiding Dell comics in their
geography text books, about the one superhero
left, the greatest superhero of them all.
Who might this paragon of power be? Not
Batman and/or Robin. They were killed in a
traffic smash-up. Superman? He's missing,
presumed dead, after a K ryptonite meteor
slammed into Metropolis. Wonder Woman? She's
,voluntarily given up her powers and become a
spokesperson for Women's Lib. The Lone Ranger
caught an arrow in the back, and Tonto ran off to
Wounded iKnee. Which leaves...
...A creation of Mayer's fertile imagination, one
very close to Superman and going by the name of
David Brinkley. In any case, that's his civilian
name. He was sent to Earth as an infant from the
planet Cronk, left a flourishing career as an ace
young reporter at a great metropolitan newspaper
for broadcasting, but missed the smell of printer's
ink. Now he's Oven up the airwaves, in both
senses, and has his feet tied securely to the copy
desk of his old newspaper. He's 42, married, the
father of two children, has a nice wife and blue
hair. He's vulnerable to only one substance:
Cronkite —and perhaps the ravages of time,
because, after eight years of retirement, his
super-powers are definitely on the wane.
He has had attacks of weakness and has lost
confidence in himself—as well as in the general
order. What could any superhero do faced with
political assassinations, racial disturbances,
Vietnam and rampant street crime? The world has
come of age and the problems seem
insurmountable.
That is how Brinkley feels until a fateful news
flash draws him unexpectedly out of his suburban
shell and back into the real world of crime and
violence. But he has been devitalized so much that
he crashes into atree in hisfirst attempt to leap tall
buildings. Is there a criminal mastermind, and a
foul plot to dispose of the last of the superheroes?
The plot thickens...
"Superfolks" is a good, old-fashioned
mis-adventure story made contemporary by liberal
doses of political intrigue, sex and some hilarious
examples of celebrity malapropisms. Mayer
handles it all with grace and ease.
And well he might. First novel or not, his name
ought to have a familiar ring to it. For 10 years he
was reporter and later a columnist for Newsday, a
great metropolitan newspaper. While he was there
he won numerous awards for writing excellence,
including a National Headliners' Club award.
Mayer seems to have kept his foot on the
accelerator the whole time in the story. It has a
sparkling beginning, just the slightest trace of
middle-pages spread and a clever end. The work is
a whole, and a whole lot of fun, due to the
author's skill and imagination. I His gibes at the
news industry and other writers have punch and
style, especially the parody on Norman Mailer's highly personal and often excessive style of
reportage.
"Superfolks" is the kind of book that could give
lightweight fiction a good name. It is some of the
best of recent efforts at the genre, written to
entertain. Give it a read. It's far better than any
night of the week on TV.

Making the Fair
Safe for violence
By ERIC GARLAND
This year's Spring Fair didn't seem to bring as many
people to Hopkins as in the past; it also escaped a rainy
washout for three straight days. What the Mardi Gras did
get, however, was a mixture of violence and police
activity that, in retrospect, has been unusually absent
from past fairs.
NMth anywhere from ten to forty thousand people on
campus for a day, drinking beer and smoking dope, taking
ninety-degree heat and waiting in long lines, it should be
expected that a few among the crowd will get punchy-by
late afternoon. Especially those few that happen to be
ragged local punks or overeager lacrosse players—it
doesn't take too many Schlitz lights or poorly-chosen
words to bring out the worst in people.
The knifing incidents in the freshman quad are general
knowledge: one Hopkins student slashed and a teenager
cut in a back-and-forth brawl around the ride area. Along
with this well-known melee, there were a number of
minor scuffles. One in particular took place about a
half-hour before the stabbings, precipitated by the same
group responsible for the later scuffles.
Characterizing the Friday night fight was a uniform
lack of sensible action by the campus police. Those
on-hand for the entire affair, and others involved in
isolated fistfights, had common complaints about the
fumblings of the blue-uniformed security force. After the
initial outburst in the freshman quad—rather serious with
one man ganged up on by local youths—the campus cops
failed to respond to repeated warnings and identifications
of the troublemakers. Instead, they waited for the arrival
of city police, making no attempts at crowd control and
staying clear of those pointed out as brawlers, the ones
who would later start the knife fights. "The cops were
Intimidated more. than anything, just scared," said one
obFrvor.

or-

%en the city police got to the freshmen quad they
received little help from campus security in the way of
rounding up the instigators. Outside of the people stabbed
or those who actually fought with the city police, the
original gang that had been repeatedly identified to the
campus police was relatively ignored (in fact, they
reappeared Sunday at the Fair, ready for more
encounters.)
Once the city police cleared the amusement area in the
freshman quad, they toliped.off a confused evening by
proceeding to the Gilman Quad, where a jazz band had
been scheduled for a 9:30 show. The band had moved
indoors to the Glass Pavilion, apparently for fear of rain. •
Unfortunately, there was little notice given to those

milling about the Quad, wondering what had become of
the performance. The police then came into the Quad,
saw the crowd of people that seemed to be loitering for
no reason, and with the ride-area hubbub fresh in their
minds, went about kicking everyone out of the area.
Numerous complaints were voiced about the over-reaction
of the police, of excessive hassling of those that happened
to have a plastic beer cup in hand.
Thus the Mardi Gras, with its theme of insanity amid
revelry, had an offshoot of violence that was grossly
mishandled at the start, and then typically over-reacted to
at the end. Next year's Fair will have that to go on.
